posts.cooked: Hello, I am wondering how I can implement April tags with photon vision to set my shooter to a specific angle based on the distance and angle from the april tag that is detected. However, I only want the shooter to adjust to that specific angle after I confirm the action with a button. The hardware I am using is a Raspberry Pi 4 and a compatible USB camera with photon vision.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked:
Read the PhotonVision docs about how to install PhotonVision, detect AprilTags, and use the data in your code:

PhotonVision Welcome to the official documentation of PhotonVision! PhotonVision is the free, fast, and easy-to-use vision processing solution for the FIRST Robotics Competition. PhotonVision is de...

Then, create a command that adjusts the shooter to the specific angle. The following article explains how to bind that command to a button:

Apart from autonomous commands, which are scheduled at the start of the autonomous period, and default commands, which are automatically scheduled whenever their subsystem is not currently in-use, ...

link_counts.title: Binding Commands to Triggers â€” FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: The documentation on photonvision does not provide examples of photonvision with a swerve. It shows examples of differential drive robots.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: If you refer to the estimated pose returned by PhotonPoseEstimator , then PhotonVision doesnâ€™t care whether your drivetrain is differential, swerve, mechanum, etc. You just update your pose estimator with the estimated pose from PhotonVision.

Yes I just realized I was thinking that the swerve itself would move based on April tag data but thatâ€™s not what I am trying to do. Just use April tag data to find the pose of the robot and calculate the angle of the shooter from that pose. However I do have a question, would the code for the April tag go as a subsystem and then the actual command to set the angle go as a command?

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked:
There are many ways to structure your code. A good one is a simple one which you and your teammates fully understand. The way you describedâ€”

Putting the vision code in a subsystem

Updating the global pose somewhere else using drivetrain encoders measurements and AprilTags data from the drivetrain and vision subsystems

Having a command in your shooter command which rotates based on the global pose

â€”is a viable way indeed. Also, if you have a turret on your robot, itâ€™d make sense to split the shooter and the turret to two subsystems.

dan:

Updating the global pose somewhere else using drivetrain encoders measurements and AprilTags data from the drivetrain and vision subsystems

By somewhere else you mean the drive subsystem, correct?
